citeinfo.origin: Priya Nanjappa, USGS Patuxent Wildlife Research Center
Dr. Michael J. Lannoo, Ph.D., Indiana University School of Medicine
citeinfo.title: Amphibians, New York State, 2000

descript.abstract: This data set portrays the distribution of 10 selected amphibians in New York State, based on historical literature and museum records from current and historical sources. The amphibians included are northern cricket frog, American toad, Cope's gray treefrog, gray treefrog, eastern newt, eastern red-backed salamander, northern two-lined salamander, mudpuppy, western lesser siren, and spring peeper.
descript.purpose: These data are intended for geographic display and analysis at the national level, and for large regional areas. The data should be displayed and analyzed at scales appropriate for 1:2,000,000-scale data. No responsibility is assumed by the U.S. Geological Survey in the use of these data.
descript.supplinf: To create maps that are similar to the maps in the National Atlas <http://nationalatlas.gov/natlas/natlasstart.asp>, amphibt.dbf can be joined to the 2000 county boundaries available from the National Atlas download page, <http://nationalatlas.gov/atlasftp.html>. For more information please visit the following sites: U.S. Amphibians Distribution Maps: <http://nova.bsuvc.bsu.edu/~mlannoo/>; North American Amphibian Monitoring Program (NAAMP) web site: <http://www.mp1-pwrc.usgs.gov/amphibs.html>; North American Reporting Center for Amphibian Malformations: <http://www.npwrc.usgs.gov/narcam/>; and FrogWeb: Amphibian Declines & Deformities: <http://www.frogweb.gov/>

theme.themekt: Scientific and Standard English Names of Amphibians and Reptiles of North America North of Mexico, with Comments Regarding Confidence in Our Understanding, Society for the Study of Amphibians and Reptiles, St. Louis, Missouri, 2000, 82 pp.

idinfo.useconst: None. Acknowledgment of the primary sources used to acquire these data and (or) the National Atlas of the United States of America is appreciated in products derived from these data.
idinfo.native: Microsoft Excel97 converted to dBASE IV for the National Atlas of the United States of America.

dataqual.logic: No checks for topological consistency were performed on this data set.
dataqual.complete: This data set includes distribution data for 10 species of amphibians in the 50 United States and the District of Columbia.

citeinfo.origin: Ball State University and Indiana University School of Medicine
citeinfo.title: Distributional History of Selected U.S. Amphibians
citeinfo.othercit: A complete source bibliography is included as a text file bundled with the downloadable data. The file is called atlas_amphib_sources.txt.

procstep.procdesc: The Microsoft Excel97 file, amphibian_data, containing fields for State, county, FIPS code, species status and data source information was received from Ball State University and modified by USGS Patuxent Wildlife Research Center. The file contained information about the distribution of 10 species of amphibians. Amphibian_data was converted to a text file and then into a dBASE IV database which is the format used by the National Atlas of the United States.

In order to geoprocess spatial files for New York State from the National Atlas Data for distribution in CUGIR, the nationwide data files were added to a map document in ArcInfo 8.2. Using the geoprocessing wizard's clip function, the spatial files were clipped to the detailed New York polygon.

enttyp.enttypd: Distribution of amphibians in the United States, by county.
enttyp.enttypds: Ball State University and Indiana University School of Medicine

attr.attrdef: The two-character abbreviation for the name of the State in which the county is located.

codesetd.codesetn: Codes for the Identification of the States, the District of Columbia and the Outlying Areas of the United States, and Associated Areas; (Federal Information Processing Standard (FIPS) 5-2): Washington, DC, National Institute of Standards and Technology.

attr.attrdef: The name of the county or county equivalent.

codesetd.codesetn: Counties and Equivalent Entities of the United States, Its Possessions, and Associated Areas, FIPS 6-4, 1990.
codesetd.codesets: U.S. Department of Commerce, National Institute of Standards and Technology

attr.attrdef: The State and county FIPS code for the county.

codesetd.codesetn: Counties and Equivalent Entities of the United States, Its Possessions, and Associated Areas, FIPS 6-4, 1990
codesetd.codesets: U.S. Department of Commerce, National Institute of Standards and Technology

attr.attrdef: Presence data for the amphibian species XXXXXX, where XXXXXX represents the species name: XXXXXX--Amphibian species Ac_cre--Acris crepitans (northern cricket frog) Bu_ame--Bufo americanus (American toad) Hy_chr--Hyla chrysoscelis (Cope?s gray treefrog) Hy_ver--Hyla vericolor (gray treefrog No_vir--Notophthalmus viridescens (eastern newt) Pl_cin--Plethodon cinereus (eastern red-backed salamander) Eu_bis--Eurycea bislineata (northern two-lined salamander) Ne_mac--Necturus maculosus (mudpuppy) Si_int--Siren intermedia (western lesser siren) Ps_cru--Pseudacris crucifer (spring peeper)

edom.edomvd: The amphibian species may be absent from the county; no survey data are available for the county and no voucher (museum specimen, collection, or confirmed sighting) data is known to exist for the county.
edom.edomvds: Ball State University and Indiana University School of Medicine

edom.edomvd: The amphibian species is believed present in the county and (or) is assumed present in the county but no current publication information or recent confirmed sightings, photographs, or collections of live animals are known to exist for the county.
edom.edomvds: Ball State University and Indiana University School of Medicine

edom.edomvd: The amphibian species is believed present in the county and has been documented by the existence of museum voucher specimens, the collection of live animals or animal tissue from live animals, or the existence of photographs or photographic vouchers of live animals from the county.
edom.edomvds: Ball State University and Indiana University School of Medicine

distinfo.distliab: Cornell University provides these geographic data "as is". The burden for determining fitness for use lies entirely with the user.
